title: Two million clicks from one email

title: ‚ÄúThe Dream 100‚Äù

title: Same interview. 700x reach.

desc: Ten years ago Dave Trott drew a triangle on a flipchat and said ‚Äúevery ad needs three things‚Äù. Impact. Communication. Persuasion.

title: Innocent know how to write copy

title: A full-time ‚Äúpizza influencer‚Äù

title: Three ways to add warmth to your CTA

title: ‚ÄúPress B anytime to Buy‚Äù
desc: CTA sticky as you scroll. My new favourite CRO experiment. 25% Press ‚ÄúB‚Äù.

title: An influencer ad that doesn't SUCK
desc: Nothing says INGORE ME quite like ‚Äú#ad‚Äù. It's lazy, it's ugly, somehow it's the norm. Don't hashtag it, own it.

title: I love True Classic's upsell

title: How Vogue tapped 5M views from a 3 year old interview

title: Rows' homepage test that doubled conversions

title: Growth Design's 60% open rate

title: Sky Bet's Perfect Offer

title: 70% of Calvin Klein's tweets are questions
desc: 100% of Ralph Lauren's tweets are statements. But ~70% of Calvin Klein's tweets are questions. What's happening?

title: Adobe's Perfect TikTok
desc: Brand Storytelling 101. You're the guide, not the hero. No-one watches TikTok for brand self-adultation. What's the coolest thing you can do with Photoshop, without mentioning Photoshop?

title: I love this abandoned cart hook
desc: ‚ÄúDid you know you can expense your...‚Äù In fact, the whole email is superb. One of a series that adds $8k / mo in revenue.

title: Should you offer a free trial?
desc: ‚ÄúMarketing is just 9-letter jargon for test‚Äù

title: One thousand replies to cold emails
desc: Last week some rather impressive stats popped up on my Twitter... I‚Äôve never seen cold outreach scale so well before. So I messaged Ryan, asking for a crash course. He obliged.

title: Posting seltzer. Making money.
desc: The ultimate abandoned cart flow. ‚ÄúI see you started an order but didn‚Äôt get round to completing it. Here‚Äôs a free one to try...‚Äù

title: How Loom Created a Category
desc: When Loom launched in 2016 it was called OpenVid. And it was just another ‚Äúeasy-to-use screen recorder‚Äù. At the time all screen recorders walked the same and talked the same. No opinions, no personality.

title: Sticker Mule's plain text emails

title: Barbie Newsjacking

title: ‚ÄúMake Ugly Ads‚Äù
desc: Less polished, more authentic. Can test ten in an afternoon. $50K return on a ‚ÄúPost-it‚Äù

title: Why is the Angostura bitters label too big?
desc: Well, it was a mistake! In 1870 two sons took over the business and decided to rebrand for an upcoming competition. One son redesigned the bottle, the other the label. Neither consulted the other, they got a label too big for the bottle.

title: Four (not boring) ways to name a new product line
desc: Personify with a human name. Call it what people say when they use it. Pull out an adjective. Call it the ‚Äújob to be done‚Äù

title: The cold email that started a $100M / yr company
desc: How Jason Cohen got his first 30 users before even building his product.

title: Reforge and the Strategic Use of Language

title: A crafty social media giveaway
desc: ‚ÄúOne comment with zero likes will win a...‚Äù Hacks two positive engagement metrics: Comments and likes on comments (to stop others winning). I'll let the results speak for themselves.

title: Innocent‚Äôs Wooly Hats

title: The chocolate that goes viral every day
desc: Tabs makes ‚Äúsex chocolate‚Äù. Last month they sold half a million worth. Oliver is the founder. A 21-year-old college kid from New York. I spoke to him on Friday. And there's one thing Tabs do ridiculously well:

title: How Chamaripa turned celeb heights into shoe sales

title: My favourite indie rock band
desc: Zendesk Alternative ‚Äî A tongue-in-cheek five-piece set up by Zendesk to prevent competitors ranking for their brand name.

title: One line. Eight Rhetorical Devices.
desc: Last week I asked you for the rhetorical devices in the line: ‚ÄúOne Scoop. Once a day. Every day.‚Äù I learnt a lot. So I'm dedicating this week's article to your answers. Alongside alliteration, repetition, tricolon we have...

title: Wine List's Counterintuitive Pricing
desc: 99% of pricing tiers ascend left to right: Cheap. Middle. Expensive. Wine List is the 1%. A mistake? Nope.

title: Veed, Miro and Canva's strategy in one line

desc: Three lovely little short cute examples of how to write cold emails that actually get opened

title: Four ways to write a CTA

title: I love Blinkist's free trial paywall
desc: What's the #1 objection to signing up for a free trial?. ‚ÄúI'll forget to cancel and get billed indefinitely‚Äù

title: 4 years. 4 AMA's. 1M views.
desc: Oosh. I love this one. The founder of Photopea churning out Reddit AMA's like they're going out of fashion

title: Seven ways to build your ‚Äúfounder brand‚Äù
desc: Here's seven real examples for how to build your ‚Äúfounder brand‚Äù on social media

title: This rebrand cost Tropicana $55M
desc: Copy is about communication. The quicker the better. Tell that to Tropicana. They tried to be clever and well... it didn't work out too great. Whoopsy daisy.

title: A crash course in improving your open rate
desc: Oosh. Open Rates are a big deal. Here's a few really simple (really smart) things you can do to improve yours. Good luck Spartan Soldier.

title: The content marketing sweet spot
desc: There's two ways people discover content. By searching for it. By people sharing it. Occasionally a piece of content does both.

title: How to grow a YouTube channel in 2022
desc: So ChrisMD makes one longform video with a load of shots. He then goes onto chop this video into 22 clips of ‚Äúclippable‚Äù shots and gets double the views than the whole original video.

title: Nine marketing examples that tap into cognitive biases
desc: Exactly what it says on the tin. My favorite nine real world examples that tap into ye ol' cognitive biases.

title: How to approach viral content marketing
desc: Mr Beast Style. Write the title. Then you make the content. Work backwards.

title: Copywriting is more like math than you suspect
desc: The same little things crop up and up and up again and again and again in copywriting. Let me teach you some fundementals, young one.

title: I love this DTC retention strategy
desc: Weekly raffle. Ship tickets with order. Group text the winner. How clever. How simple.

title: The tale of two Twitter strategies
desc: The Kyiv Post and The Kyiv Independent are both reporting the Ukraine War. The Kyiv Post shares article links. The Kyiv Independent condenses news into tweets and threads.

title: How Basecamp makes $99/month feel cheap
desc: How Basecamp makes $99/month feel cheap. Sets expectations. Comparison table. Price anchoring.

title: My favourite ‚ÄúMeta Images‚Äù
desc: Your ‚ÄúMeta Image‚Äù is the image that appears when you share a link online. It's the most important image you make.

desc: How Canva and Basecamp stop competitors leeching off their brand name

title: If you want to grow on social make yourself easy to sum up
desc: If you want to grow on social media make yourself easy to sum up. 6 examples.

title: I love Billboards designed for social
desc: The idea is simple. You rent a digital billboard for 24hrs. You write something funny / controversial / clever. You post it on social. And because ‚Äúit's on a billboard, wow!‚Äù it goes viral.

title: My Twitter Inspiration Handbook
desc: When I started on Twitter I had no idea what I was doing. So I made one big Google Doc where I started saving all the best ‚Äúbrand tweets‚Äù and grouped them into categories. Today, it's ready to share. I hope you find it useful.

title: 17 tips for great copywriting
desc: No filler. No wasted words. Only gold. Pound for pound the best copywriting article on the web. 17 copywriting tips. Put your feet up and enjoy.

title: Neiman's magazine ads
desc: I've been chatting to the owner of a decorative concrete company. Each month they pay $600/mo for an ad in a local magazine that gets sent to 7000 wealthy homes in Georgia. Last 3 months they've made $75,000 from these ads.

title: Apple‚Äôs ‚ÄúShot on iPhone‚Äù campaign
desc: I must have seen 100 Samsung ads last year. I don‚Äôt remember any of them. Too much boring information. Shot on iPhone is three words, no information. It doesn't dwell on features. Instead, it brings to life the outcome.

title: Barilla's pasta playlist
desc: January 2021. Italian pasta producer Barilla created Spotify playlists that are the exact length of time it takes to cook different types of pasta.

title: Cronitor's Little Side-Project
desc: ‚ÄúCron jobs‚Äù are what developers write to schedule tasks. They're hard to remember. So Cronitor made a little side project to help. Developers search ‚ÄúCron job every [time interval]‚Äù. And Crontab (the little side project) gives you the code to copy and paste. Lovely.

title: People Warm to People, Not Brands
desc: It took Watford F.C. ten years to get 170k YouTube subscribers. It took Watford F.C. goalkeeper Ben Foster one year to get 1M YouTube subscribers.

title: Arc'teryx's TikTok Fame
desc: A TikTok trend of people taking showers in Arc'teryx's extra waterproof jackets (started by Arc'teryx last year). ~111M cumulative views.

title: One Tweet. Eighty media placements.
desc: Guy on Tinder insults a woman's ASOS dress. ASOS update their site making her the new model. Story goes completely viral. 80+ media placements.

title: A Table of Contents can work wonders for SEO
desc: Anchor links are included in the SERP. Keywords rank long-tail in Google. Better UX means longer session duration (a ranking factor).

title: A simple idea that‚Äôs makes Gillette $60M/yr
desc: In the early 90's Gillette started posting free shaving kits to men to celebrate their 18th birthday. The idea was simple ‚Äî Hook men at the age they decide their shaving brand for life.

title: Signal's Instagram Ads
desc: Signal is a private messenger app. May 2021. They made Instagram ads to show all the personal data that Facebook sells about you. Facebook banned them. Signal replied with a viral blog post.

title: Taylordle
desc: Newsjacking is the art of piggybacking on trending topics to draw attention to your own brand. Yesterday I saw a good example. A Taylor Swift themed Wordle. From a Taylor Swift themed podcast.

title: The Vegetable Name Change
desc: June 2018. Belgian supermarket Delhaize changed the names of their fruit and veg to encourage more kids to eat them. Carrots became Orange rockets. Courgettes became Troll Bats. Sales increased by 151%.

title: 7 Backlinks in 27 minutes
desc: When I made Copywriting Examples the goal was to rank #1 on Google. I need backlinks. So last week I texted anyone who'd ‚Äúinterviewed‚Äù me in the last two years asking if they could update the article.

title: How Convert Kit grew from $1.5k to $100k MRR
desc: This week I read an excellent thread from Nathan Barry explaining how he used direct sales to grow his email marketing platform. Here's four lessons. a) Start with a niche. b) Don't sell. Ask about frustrations. c) Remove the biggest objection. d) Always ask for referrals.

title: Worldle's referral loop
desc: Wordle is a simple word game that's taken over the world recently. On 99% of sites if you click ‚Äúshare‚Äù you get a link. On Wordle, if you click ‚Äúshare‚Äù your scoreboard is copied to your clipboard for you to paste onto social directly.

title: Kapwing's YouTube strategy
desc: Kapwing's a meme maker. I love their YouTube strategy. Finds memes about to go viral. Uploads ‚Äúhow to make meme‚Äù videos to YouTube. Hundreds of thousands start Googling. Watch Kapwing's tutorial. Which uses their app to make meme

title: A brilliant response to Amazon cloning your product
desc: Peak Design's response to Amazon copying their ‚ÄúEveryday Sling‚Äù is nothing short of genius.

title: My guide to brand positioning
desc: Positioning is like finding a seat on a crowded bus. Most brands sleepwalk onto the bus and sit on top of one another. The smart brands look left, right, find an empty row, paint their logo on it and start singing sweetly like the Sirens

title: Rewriting landing pages with a pro copywriter
desc: Last week I asked people on social media to submit their companies' landing pages and I‚Äôd rewrite them. Well, we did it! So I teamed up with Annie Maguire, one of the best copywriters in the business. Hopefully this gives you an insight into the mind of a pro copywriter.

title: How I promote my content
desc: June 2019 I wrote my first marketing article. A year later my email list hit 19,000. No ads. No connections. No existing audience. The site grew because I learned how to promote my content on the internet. Here's my process.

title: The best word of mouth strategies in the world
desc: Less than 1/1000 businesses have a proper word of mouth strategy. Yet they pull in customers just as reliably as paid ads for a fraction of the cost.

title: Growth Loops
desc: Most people think you build a product then you market it. Growth loops mean building the marketing into your product.

title: How LadBaby started a movement
desc: January 2018. Mark Hoyle (LadBaby) was a graphic designer with fifty thousand YouTube subscribers. Last week he and wife Rox equalled The Beatles record of 3 consecutive UK Christmas No.1's. Their story is a masterclass in how to start a movement. Let me share some lessons.

title: The marketing genius of Lil Nas X
desc: This is the story of how Lil Nas X went from college dropout sleeping on his sister‚Äôs couch to breaking Mariah Carey‚Äôs record for the most consecutive weeks at No. 1 ‚Äî in just seven months.

title: Real Marketing
desc: Lifeless marketing is everywhere and we copy it without thinking. So I thought I'd share some examples of real stuff.

title: ‚ÄúMichelin Guide‚Äù Marketing
desc: An old school content marketing story. France, 1900. Andre and Edouard Michelin had just started making tyres. The problem was there were less than 300 cars in France. So hoping to encourage car ownership they published the world's first ‚ÄúMichelin Guide‚Äù.

title: Why Burger King sponsored Stevenage F.C.
desc: You have to admire Burger King's creativity. For the 19/20 football season they sponsored Stevenage F.C. all to get their logo in FIFA 20. They then offered rewards for gamers to play as Stevenage, score goals, and share on Twitter.

title: ¬£8k Instagram Giveaway ‚Üí 1M followers
desc: Last week Molly-Mae did an Instagram giveaway. She spent ¬£8k on gifts. Her reward was 1M new followers and subscribers across Instagram and YouTube. That's < 1p / new fan. Possibly the best ROI I've seen. Let's break it down.

title: Using Unsplash for brand awareness and backlinks
desc: One of my pals, Max, works for a paddleboard startup. They had some nice images from photoshoots. So he made an account on Unsplash (the photo discovery platform) and uploaded them. Five months later the images have 6M views. And 24k downloads.

title: The marketing genius of Andrew Schulz
desc: Let‚Äôs start in 2017. Andrew Schulz had been killing it in the New York comedy clubs for over a decade. But no network would give him a shot. So he filmed his own special. And handed it to the networks on a plate.

title: A crash course in getting press and building links
desc: Carrie Rose is the co-founder of Rise at Seven, a creative SEO agency. Over the last year I‚Äôve been consistently blown away by how easy she makes getting press look. And it‚Äôs not press for press's sake. The reward is high quality backlinks which help her clients rank for ultra-competitive search terms.

title: My guide to conversational copywriting
desc: Conversational copy is writing how you talk. No sales megaphone. No corporate drone. Just a conversation. But that's easier said than done. So I've put together this guide (packed with examples) to help teach you.

title: Dave Gerhardt's 1 line sales email
desc: Imagine you're trying to sell an exec coaching program. Here's the 1 line email Dave Gerhardt would send. The goal is simple. Get a reply. A reply gives you something to work with.

title: How brands make friends on Twitter
desc: Fast coins term ‚ÄúFastronaut‚Äù. Tweets ‚Äúreply and we'll give your profile pic a Fastronaut helmet‚Äù

title: Ahrefs' Social Proof
desc: I love how Ahrefs does social proof. Different testimonials for different types of customer. People like seeing customers that look like them.

title: 27 words that sum up the psychology of copywriting
desc: ‚ÄúPeople will do anything for those who encourage their dreams, justify their failures, allay their fears, confirm their suspicions, and help them throw rocks at their enemies.‚Äù ‚Äî Blair Warren. Let's look at some examples.

title: How J√ºrgen Klopp makes fans smile
desc: Yesterday I saw this letter Liverpool manager, J√ºrgen Klopp, wrote to a young schoolboy dealing with anxiety. It‚Äôs remarkably thoughtful. But it didn‚Äôt surprise me. Klopp's been making people smile ever since he became a manager.

title: How Jeff Johnson sold Nike's first shoes
desc: The story of how Phil Knight and Jeff Johnson drove to track meets all over the Pacific Northwest and sold more shoes than you can imagine out of the boots of their car.

title: Counterpunch like Carl
desc: March 24. Popular Instagram account DudeWithSign takes aim at home workout videos. March 26. Beachbody‚Äôs CEO, Carl Daikeler, fires back, rallying his followers to post their home workouts with pride this Saturday.

title: How Steve Jobs clarified Apple's message
desc: January 1983. Apple finish production of their latest computer, Lisa. Steve Jobs launches it with a nine-page ad in the New York Times. It's nine pages of geek speak. Nobody outside NASA is interested. Lisa sells just 10,000 units. Steve is fired from Apple.

title: The most creative Coronavirus company pivots
desc: Evo Entertainment converted their parking lot into a drive-in movie theatre. Shake Shack launched ‚ÄúDIY burger kits‚Äù with a free cooking tutorial. New Balance switched production from shoes to masks.

title: Grubhub's link building strategy
desc: How Grubhub's local link building strategy saw them generate 50% more organic traffic than their competitors in the online food delivery market

title: How Chewy delights customers
desc: Chewy's marketing strategy is simple: Delight customers and they‚Äôll become life long customers. This article explains how Chewy's built a business around great customer service.

title: How a creative Google ad got an investor's attention
desc: Tadabase's CEO, Moe Levine, was a long time admirer of investor, Mark Suster. So he set up some Google ads targeting Suster‚Äôs name, reminding him that he's yet to invest in no-code startups.

title: Surprising a customer with birthday cake
desc: It all started when Lemonade sent a personalised birthday email to loyal customer, Andrew. Andrew was touched and thanked them on Twitter.

title: My favourite low-budget viral ads
desc: 30 years ago, to get millions of views you needed a Super Bowl budget. Today all you need is a phone and an idea.

title: How to build a website which converts email subscribers
desc: 12.9% of first time Marketing Examples users end up as a email subscribers. It's fair to say it's one of the best websites in the world at converting passers-by into email subscribers. This case study gives a step-by-step analysis.

title: The genius of no name's brand
desc: no name is a ‚Äúno nonsense, no frills‚Äù supermarket brand in Canada. Nothing special. A lot of supermarket brands share these ‚Äúvalues‚Äù. The hard part is communicating them in a way that people remember.

title: A story about my dad and PPC ads
desc: My dad runs a small study skills company in the UK. It's an old-school business. Up until last year, the only marketing he's ever done was sending flyers to schools. But, over time, flyers had stopped working so well, so he started thinking about running digital ads.

title: How to write a landing page title
desc: Most things in marketing are unimportant. And we stress about them. Landing page headlines are important. And we don't stress about them. I've spent the past fortnight reading 500 landing page titles and talking to copywriting experts. This is what I've learnt:

title: Turning a restaurant robbery into a viral ad
desc: On the 16th December 2015 Frijoles & Frescas Tacos gets robbed. The next day, store owner, Greg Carlson, releases the security footage. Except he's added captions which turn the burglary into a story about how all the thieves wanted was their delicious tacos.

title: Refactoring UI: A lesson in high prices
desc: How Adam Wathan and Steve Schoger escaped the dogma of e-book pricing and made $1.35M selling Refactoring UI, their design book.

title: How I got 2,000 new subscribers from Product Hunt
desc: Last Wednesday I launched Marketing Examples to Product Hunt. It received more than 1,500 upvotes, was voted Product of the Week, and my email list zoomed from 1,300 to 3,300 in the space of 72 hours. This is the step by step account of how I did it.

title: How Nomad List dominates longer tail keywords
desc: A detailed case study explaining how Nomad List autogenerates several thousand indexed pages which hoover up organic traffic from long tail keyword phrases.

title: Email Segmentation ‚Äî A practical example
desc: Indie Hackers is an online community of independent entrepreneurs, with a pretty sizeable email list. Throughout 2019 they‚Äôve moved away from one generic email digest and started offering users the option of up to eight tailored newsletters

title: The genius of Tesla's marketing strategy
desc: Tesla have zero advertising budget. The focus is on turning customers into fans. The result is quite an extraordinary marketing strategy which I've broken down:

title: Let your customers write your copy for you
desc: Copywriting doesn't require the ‚Äúperfect line‚Äù or a ‚Äúflash of inspiration‚Äù. Just talk to your customers, listen to what they're saying, and let them do the work for you. This article explains how Design Academy does just that

title: Using GIPHY for free brand awareness
desc: All you need is a Giphy brand channel. Then any GIF you upload is publically available on Giphy's search engine. And there's nothing stopping you slipping in your logo, product, or even URL.

title: How Rev. Chris grew 100k Instagram followers
desc: For two and and a half years Rev. Chris Lee's Instagram account grew steadily. He posted mostly pictures of himself, his family, and the church. In July 2019 things changed. Chris started uploading ‚Äú60 second sermons‚Äù.

title: 6 keys to sharing content on Twitter
desc: How you share is just as important as what you share. In one second someone subconsciously decides whether to engage with your content on Twitter or to scroll by. These tips are about optimising for that one second.

title: How Volvo won the Super Bowl (without running an ad)
desc: How Volvo's interception stole the show at the 2015 Super Bowl. Whenever you saw any other car commercial during the Super Bowl you could win a Volvo XC 60 for a loved one. All you had to do was was tweet why they deserved the car using the hashtag #VolvoContest during the commercial.

title: 7 practical ways to write copy that converts
desc: Conversion copywriting is an art. Here are 7 practical tips that you can implement today to make your landing page convert better.

title: SEO project marketing
desc: Make side projects. Host them on your own domain. Get them in front of the press. The idea is press exposure results in articles (and backlinks). And because the projects are hosted on your own domain any ‚Äúlink juice‚Äù flows to other pages on your website helping them rank better.

title: Podia's hub of competitor comparison pages
desc: How Podia built a hub of ‚Äú[competitor] + alternative‚Äù pages pulling in 5,500 organic traffic each month

title: Basic SEO and Specsavers' FAQ page
desc: The most common SEO mistake is relying on a single page website. Every new page is a new opportunity to target and rank for a search term. So if you‚Äôre dumping all your content on one page you‚Äôre limiting the number of search terms you can rank well for.

title: CD Baby's confirmation email
desc: Back in 1998, when Derek Sivers first founded CD Baby, their order confirmation email was the regular: ‚ÄúYour order has shipped today. Please let us know if it doesn‚Äôt arrive. Thank you for your business.‚Äù

title: Share a Coke
desc: If I told you Coca-Cola's sales in Australia increased ~7% in 2011 you'd probably guess they changed the taste or the price. Nope. They simply replaced their logo with 150 of the most popular teenage names and encouraged people to ‚Äúshare a coke‚Äù.

title: How to get Tom Hanks on your podcast
desc: This article explains how Chris Hardwick from the Nerdist podcast used a vintage 1934 Smith Corona typewriter to quite creatively bribe Tom Hanks onto the Nerdist podcast back in 2012.

title: What to do if Joe Rogan recommends your product?
desc: Iron Neck found themselves in the much sought after position of having Joe Rogan recommend their product. Well, they chopped up the footage into a video and ran ads targeting Joe's audience.

title: The 1903 Tour de France
desc: The 1903 Tour de France was set up as a ‚Äúside project‚Äù which ended up changing the fortunes of its parent newspaper L'Auto

title: Marketing tools are damaging your SEO. And how to fix it.
desc: It's no secret that a site's ‚Äúperformance‚Äù is a ranking factor for search. But how does Google actually measure it? Well, open up Chrome DevTools, click the Audits tab, then Run Audits and you'll see that ‚ÄúPerformance‚Äù is made up from 6 metrics

title: How to get 30,000 Hacker News visitors to your website
desc: How Adriaan van Rossum drove more than 30k visitors to his website from Hacker News

title: Why Notion's sign-up form converts so well
desc: In three years looking at landing pages, I‚Äôve never come across a sign-up flow better at converting than Notions. Let‚Äôs get into it.

title: How Fortnite changed the way video games were marketed
desc: How Fortnite flipped the growth funnel on its head and forever changed the way video games are marketed.

title: Reaching 3.7 million people posting canvases to YouTubers
desc: 140 Canvas printed bespoke canvas', posted them to the PO boxes of YouTubers around the world and ended up with their product getting seen by over 3.7 million people.

title: How step by step keyword research led to an SEO goldmine
desc: How keyword research led Thomas Cook to an SEO goldmine and which pulls in an additional 450,000 organic users per month ...

title: A much improved newsletter sign up flow
desc: Asking to be added to your recipients' address book results in much improved email open rates

title: Costly Signalling Theory
desc: An awareness of costly signalling theory is invaluable in understanding the psychology of marketing.
